info.author: Matthew Jowett
info.description:
outcp
=====

Outgoing TCP port tester for Python 3.4+
----------------------------------------

|pypi|

An outgoing TCP port tester for python using http.client.

It works by sending a HTTP request to the chosen host (resolved to IP)
and TCP ports, then retrieving the HTTP code from the response header(s)
or timeout.

It can be used as a library or CLI-command/executable.

Feel free to pull request, request a feature or report bugs.

Install using pip
-----------------

Install the package via pip:

``pip install outcp``

Install from source
-------------------

Clone the repository from Github:

``git clone https://github.com/m-jowett/outcp``

Enter the repo folder:

``cd outcp``

Build the package:

``python setup.py sdist``

Enter the dist folder:

``cd dist``

Install the package via pip:

``pip install outcp-1.0.1.zip``

Features
--------

test()
~~~~~~

|test Example|

test(port=-1, hostname=“”)

-  port: (int) TCP port
-  hostname: (str) Host, can be a domain or IP.

testui()
~~~~~~~~

|testui Example|

|testui Example2|

testui(portlist=“”, namelist=“”, hostname=“”, format=1)

-  portlist: (list/int) List of ports converted into integers, can also
   be a single integer for one port.
-  namelist: (list/str) List of port names/labels converted into
   strings, can also be a single string for one name.
-  hostname: (str) Host, can be a domain or IP.
-  format: (1) (int)
-  1 - Table with dynamic spacing, according to var sizes.
-  0 - Table with static values (may not line up correctly).

main()
~~~~~~

|main Example|

main()

Run when the script is executed.

| Asks the user to input the hostname(s), port(s) and port label(s) (if
  any).
| These are separated by a space.
